founders_message.title: Founder & Chairman
message: When I first dreamt of starting my own business, I was inspired by the love that I have for my family more than anything else. I never imagined that such a simple dream would one day turn into a bigger reality - becoming one of the largest food enterprises in the Philippines. Now, it has become a home to other families as well.

Ever since, we have treated our employees as an extension of our own family. I always believe that when we are able to look after their welfare, they will in turn take care of our business and treat it as their own.

It is for this reason that I urge each one of you to lead your team with the same passion, understanding, and vigor as you do your job. As leaders, you play a vital role in helping us make this home flourish.

Your leadership should inspire your people to be better in what they do believing that it will fulfill their own sense of purpose. I trust that you will be our partner in nurturing the people that we have and in continuously making their stay in our home a truly meaningful one.

Let this playbook be your tool in guiding your people in their journey here in CDO. We depend on you in creating a prosperous home as we continue to remain relevant and evolve as a family that serves a bigger community.

Together, let us strengthen our bond as a family, as one Ka-Republika so that with One Heart and in One Home we will be able to fulfill our purpose and thrive as One CDO, continuously serving our customers and consumers with food that brings them Home.

playbook_overview.description: The Leader's Playbook is a comprehensive but easy-to-use manual that provides guidelines for leaders like you on managing your staff's employee experience using the current HR processes and tools.
playbook_overview.structure: This playbook offers the support that you need to carry out your role as a leader, arranged based on the employee's life cycle within the organization.
playbook_overview.navigation: Icons and underlined words or phrases that are clickable are embedded in this toolkit to help in the ease of navigation.
playbook_overview.disclaimer: Although this playbook intends to help you lead effectively, it does not guarantee to have all the answers. In situations that are extraordinarily complex, unusual, or new, it is still recommended to work with or consult your HR Business Partner.
playbook_overview.expectation: You are expected to be fully oriented with the contents of this playbook. Should there be any changes in the HR standards and guidelines and any other related information that will not be immediately reflected in the playbook, the Company, through Corporate HRAD, will make sure to notify its employees.

employee_experience_concept.definition: A meaningful employee experience in CDO can be likened to finding a place called 'HOME' where one's capabilities are valued, recognized, and maximized throughout the employee's stay. Key to this experience is the leader's support, participation, and guidance.

framework.main_goal: Attract the right talent to the CDO HOME.

leader_role.title: Your role as Leader:
responsibilities: Identify the right talent needed to perform the job.
Determine selection criteria that will be used as reference in assessing the candidate's qualifications.
Represent and promote the Company's vision, mission, values, and philosophy.
Ensure awareness and compliance with the hiring guidelines.

framework.key_principle: Deciding on who to hire are among the most important choices that a leader will have to make. It is essential to acquire talents who can eagerly contribute to the growth potential of the organization. As Foodsphere, Inc. wants to invest in individuals with the right attitude, aptitude, and personal attributes as well as good cultural fit for the company, the leader must be able to drive this by carefully selecting qualified and diverse workforce that will help achieve the organization's goal.

stages_of_hiring_process.title: Stages of the Hiring Process
stages_of_hiring_process.note: All hiring should be based on an approved plantilla. Hiring outside of the approved plantilla must be approved by the President. In cases when there is a directive to cut on headcount, any additional headcount must first be approved by the President.

stages.description: Based on an approved strategic and operational manpower needs, hiring managers trigger the request for hire and provide HR with a detailed job description.

HR-Recruitment sources applicants through different means like job advertisements, job fairs, social media, job sites (ex. LinkedIn, Jobstreet etc.), referrals, and internal recruitment (within the company).

HR-Recruitment facilitates the screening by conducting phone calls, interviews and administering assessment tests. Favorable results will be passed on to the hiring manager who will conduct the succeeding interviews.

Hiring managers provide feedback to HR-Recruitment and work together to generate hiring decisions - based on the applicant's performance on different aspects of the recruitment pipeline, such as interviews and standardized tests.

HR gives the job offer to successful candidates, which includes details on role and responsibilities, salary, location, and benefits. Applicants may negotiate on certain terms, and HR reaches out to the hiring manager for any support needed.

interview_levels.title: Interview Levels
interview_levels.description: As part of the recruitment and selection process, applicants go through a series of interviews depending on the job level/rank of the position being applied for.

internal_hiring_process.title: Internal Hiring Process
process_steps: Recruitment to send a monthly vacancy update to all email users.
Employee to prepare a Letter of Intent (LOI) and secure the approval from immediate superior prior to submission of application.
Once LOI is approved, employee to send an email to interapply@cdo.com.ph.
Recruitment to screen and evaluate internal applications following the standard assessment process.
Recruitment to discuss the profile of the candidate to the hiring manager.
Provide an update to the employee on the status of his/her application.
If the employee passed the assessment, releasing manager to prepare and submit the RPA to the HRBP.
HRBP to process the RPA and secure the signature of the receiving manager.

leaders_goal.description: The leader's role in filling up a vacancy is to raise a requisition and participate in the entire interview process from the preparation of the Personnel Requisition Form (PRF) to the final recommendation of candidates.
leaders_goal.extended_goal: Since our Company depends on the quality and talent of its employees, deciding on who to hire are among the most important choices that you will make as a leader. You must try to select, develop, and retain a qualified and diverse workforce that will promote and support the Company in achieving its organizational goals. At each stage of the employment process, from determining your staffing needs through recruitment, interviewing, and selection, you will be presented with opportunities to make choices that will lead to the effective management of your operations. You may seek advice and guidance from our Recruitment Team in making these choices, but selecting the candidate that best meets your needs will rest upon you.
equal_opportunity_means: Provide fair and equal access to all available jobs, training, and promotional opportunities
Apply all policies and practices consistently to applicants and employees

Do not differentiate among applicants or employees on the basis of race, color, nationality, religion, gender identity or expression, physical or mental disability, medical condition, ancestry, marital status, age, etc.

internal_hiring_process.important_note: Releasing manager should ensure a proper turnover of the employee's current responsibilities before he/she officially transfers to the new department/section.

interviewing_101.title: INTERVIEWING 101
interviewing_101.subtitle: Facilitate a smooth interview process and create a positive impression on prospective candidates by preparing well.

job_interview_definition.title: Job Interview
job_interview_definition.definition: A job interview is a conversation that occurs between a potential employer and a job applicant, where the employer has the opportunity to assess and appraise the qualifications and general fitness of the applicant for the job opening.
job_interview_definition.objective: The objective of an interview is to know the applicant more by gathering information about his/her profile, competencies, and work experience (if applicable) and use them against the defined selection criteria to be able to choose the most qualified candidate.

leader_goal_as_interviewer.title: Your Goal as a Leader
goals: Treat all applicants in a fair and equal manner
Evaluate applicants effectively based on clearly defined set of selection criteria
Complete the interview process quickly including any related documentation
Choose the best candidate for the job
leader_goal_as_interviewer.preparation_importance: It is important for leaders (as interviewers) to prepare well for the interview in order to facilitate a smooth process. Preparation includes coordinating with the concerned authorities, setting the most appropriate schedule and venue, and visualizing the interview proper, i.e. what questions to ask, how to open and close the interview, etc.
leader_goal_as_interviewer.important_note: Whenever you conduct an interview, you represent FSI. A good interview experience for the candidate will leave a positive impression for the Company even if no job offer will be made in the end. However, a bad interview may result in a bad image for the Company, which can be shared by the applicant through friends, relatives, and social media.

steps.description: Identify the competencies to describe the desired candidate (experience, knowledge, education, and intellectual, interpersonal, and motivational competencies). This is your job/candidate profile.
Select those who best match your job/candidate profile for interview.

steps.action: Inform or arrange an interview schedule
steps.description: Inform or arrange an interview schedule with the candidate through the Recruitment team. Ensure that the interview will be conducted in a quiet and private place, free of distractions and interruptions (applies whether the interview will be held virtually or in person). Do not be late in the interview schedule. Allot a maximum of one (1) hour for the interview.

Prepare interview questions or check out guide questions to allow a smooth flow of conversation with the candidate. Ask questions that draw out the candidate's competencies in relation to the competencies necessary to effectively perform the job.
Review the candidate's resume and supporting materials shortly before the interview to refresh your memory.

After the interview, record your evaluation and recommendation in the interview evaluation form that will be provided by the Recruitment team or, in the absence of an evaluation form, prepare your own interview rating sheet.

steps.title: Set the interview climate
steps.description: Choose a schedule and a venue that will allow you to conduct the interview with no distractions or interruptions. BE ON TIME! This applies even if the interview will be conducted online. Focusing on the applicant will allow you to gather as much information as you need as well as fairly assess his/her qualifications.

steps.title: Establish rapport with the applicant
steps.description: Try to put the applicant at ease - greet them with a warm friendly smile, introduce yourself, shake their hands (if face-to-face), and ask simple questions like, 'How was your day?', 'Have you had a hard time finding our office?'

steps.title: Set the agenda
steps.description: Describe the interview structure, i.e. how the interview will proceed, who will be involved (if it's a panel).

steps.title: Take notes
steps.description: This will help you ask follow-up questions and recall specific details about the applicant. Notes need not be verbatim; key words or phrases will do.

steps.title: Listen carefully
steps.description: Do not anticipate the answers of the applicant. Reserve judgment until after the applicant has finished answering.

steps.title: Ask questions
steps.description: Begin with relatively simple questions based on information included in the applicant's CV or resume. Then focus on behavioral-based questions that will allow the applicant to talk about his/her previous experiences and achievements.

steps.title: Maintain control
steps.description: If the applicant gets off-track, ask a specific question that will bring him/her back to the interview.

steps.title: Allow opportunity for questions
steps.description: Before ending the interview, give the applicant the opportunity to ask questions and try to answer them to the best of your knowledge. Do not give false or incomplete information.

steps.title: Close the interview
steps.description: Ask whether the candidate has anything more to tell you or any questions. Explain the next step in the process. Thank the candidate. Complete your notes and/or rating sheet (if any).

behavioral_based_interview.title: Behavioral-based Interview
behavioral_based_interview.definition: Behavioral interview is a structured interviewing approach that focuses on asking questions to identify past behaviors and successes that closely relate to situations the candidates will encounter in the job for which they have applied for. This is based on the premise that past behavior is the most accurate predictor of future behavior.
behavioral_based_interview.purpose: The candidate has the opportunity to demonstrate their potential for succeeding in the new job by providing concrete examples of how they used specific behaviors or skills to handle certain situations based on their past experience. This helps the interviewer get an accurate picture of not only what the candidate can do, but how they do it.

star_method.title: STAR Method
star_method.description: Part of behavioral interviewing is the use of the STAR method, which was introduced by Development Dimensions International (DDI), an international human resources and leadership development consultancy. The STAR method helps one capture complete information about how someone has performed on the job. It is one of the simplest and most effective ways to communicate in an interview or even when providing feedback.
star_method.purpose: Using this method in a behavioral interview allows the candidate to tell stories about themselves based on past experiences and behavior, which will help you draw better conclusions about their skill and job fit.

components.description: Ask the candidate to explain the situation to set the context/background
example_questions: Tell me about a time when...
Think of a situation where you...

components.description: Ask to describe the problem or challenge and the task that needs to be achieved
Ask about the actions taken to handle the situation and overcome the challenge
Ask to describe the outcome of the action and its impact
example_questions: What was the result of your actions?

behavioral_sample_questions.title: Behavioral-based Sample Guide Questions
behavioral_sample_questions.important_note: Ask only questions that specifically pertain to the candidate's skills, knowledge, abilities, and interests related to the position, as described on the requisition and job description, based on the predetermined selection criteria. Questions related to gender, sexual orientation, age, marital status, color, race, religion, national origin, medical condition, pregnancy, or disabilities are inappropriate and must be avoided.

openness_and_collaboration.title: On Openness & Collaboration
questions: Describe a time when you had to collaborate with a team member in another department in your company. How did you overcome the differences in department goals?

Tell me about a time when you had to collaborate with a member of your team who was not responsive. How did you handle that situation? Were you able to fulfill your responsibilities and hit your goals?
Tell me about a time when you worked with a team to solve a problem. What was the situation? How were you involved? What steps did you take? What was the outcome?
Describe a time when you disagreed with a team member. How did you resolve the problem?
Can you give me an example of a time you faced conflict while working on a team? How did you handle/manage that situation and still fulfill your responsibilities?

integrity.title: On Integrity
questions: Tell me about a time when you had to choose between making an easy decision and making the right decision.
How have you dealt with failure in the past?
Do others consider you trustworthy? Tell me of a situation when this has been manifested.
Tell me about a time when you need to admit a mistake that you made.
Tell me of a situation in which you had to make a sacrifice in order to stay true to your values.

passion_for_customers_and_consumers.title: On Passion for Customers and Consumers
questions: Give me an example of when you had to interact with a difficult client/customer. What were the circumstances of the interaction? How did you handle this difficulty? Were you able to change the experience from negative to positive?
Tell me about a time you went above and beyond what was expected to please a customer?
Give me an example where you did not meet a client's expectations. What happened and how did you attempt to fix it?
Tell me about a time you thought you communicated clearly but were misunderstood. What happened and how did you handle the situation?
Give me an example of a time when you had to explain something fairly complex to a frustrated client or coworker. How did you make sure they understood you?

innovation_and_entrepreneurship.title: On Innovation and Entrepreneurship
questions: Tell me about a time when you took an innovative approach to solve an issue.
Tell me about a time your innovative idea didn't work out. What did you learn from it?
How have you used innovation to overcome workplace challenges?
Tell me about a time you used your knowledge of your organization to come up with an idea or project and had it approved.
Have you ever run over budget? Why did that happen, and how did you handle it?

love_for_god.title: On Love for God
questions: Tell me about a time when you initiated activities that had been helpful to others or to a certain group/community?
Describe a time when you think you had positively influence another person.
Tell me about a time when you had to ensure that diversity and inclusion was observed in the workplace.

questions.question: Are we open to hiring fresh graduates or candidates without prior work experience?
questions.answer: Yes, although our priority is to hire experienced candidates, there are roles that do not require such and are open to accepting fresh graduates or candidates without prior work experience, but who possess good potential.

questions.question: Are we open to hiring of employee's relatives?
questions.answer: FSI employees' relatives up to the second degree of consanguinity or affinity are not allowed to apply for regular, contractual, or project-based employment. They may only be employed on the following conditions:
conditions: Prospective applicant will not be directly reporting to or working with the relative employee within the same section or department
Prospective applicant meets the basic requirements of the job
Approval, along with a justification letter, is obtained from the Supervisor, Section Head/Department Head, Division Head, and President

special_conditions.ojt_and_seasonal: Hiring of employees' relatives are only allowed for OJT or during peak season provided that the following conditions are met:
requirements: Seasonal employees or OJTs will not directly report to their relatives
S/he will not be in the same section or department as their relatives

questions.question: Are we open to re-hiring previous employees?
questions.answer: Yes, the Company allows rehiring of a previous employee depending on the following conditions:
conditions: A previous regular employee can be rehired six (6) months after his/her separation with the Company

A previous seasonal employee can be rehired as a seasonal employee if s/he has been recommended by his/her immediate superior, or as a regular employee if s/he does not have a relative who is an active employee of the Company
A previous contractual employee can be rehired as a probationary/regular employee
The employee has shown satisfactory performance during his/her previous stint with the Company
The employee resigned on a voluntary basis and not due to termination for a company violation

The employee has no derogatory or disciplinary action record while employed with the Company or in any of its affiliated companies, and in any of his/her succeeding employers after leaving the Company
questions.note: All applicants under this category should still undergo the usual selection and hiring process and the terms of employment.

framework.main_goal: Welcome your new staff into the CDO HOME. Create a positive new hire experience by facilitating a seamless integration.

leader_role.title: Your role as Leader:
responsibilities: Clarify job expectations by ensuring that the new employee understands how to translate expectations in their day-to-day activities and how their role impacts the department's priorities.
Communicate CDO's strategic priorities, history, values, and culture.
Provide regular feedback on their performance and identify support to bridge any gaps.

onboarding_definition.title: ONBOARDING
onboarding_definition.description: Onboarding is the process of facilitating all necessary organizational actions that support new employee integration and help them function in their role effectively within the organization. It occurs in the period between offer acceptance until full integration into the CDO family. This stage is critical because as early as Day 1, new hires are already imagining how their life is going to be during their stay in the organization.

orientation.definition: one part of the onboarding process
characteristics: a structured event that focuses on the information the employee needs to know to get started
awareness on the organizational structure, policies and procedures, team or people to work with, ways of working

can last anywhere from 3 months to a year, depending on the roles and responsibilities of the position and the amount of organizational knowledge and understanding necessary in order to succeed in the role
aims to align the new employee with the company's culture, shared vision, mission, and values
focuses on strengthening the employee's connection to the organization and its people

importance_of_onboarding.title: Importance of Proper Onboarding
importance_of_onboarding.description: An established and effective employee onboarding program will help in the successful integration of a new hire in CDO. It is vital not only to the success of the team, but also to the productivity and longevity of the new employee.
benefits: Reduce anxiety and stress for the new employee
Prevent future spending on re-recruiting and training

success_factors.description: New hires will become successful in their jobs and make immediate contributions to the team if they:
factors: understand their role's impact to the team
integrate well into the culture of the organization

did_you_know.title: DID YOU KNOW?
statistics: According to 7 Need-to-Know Facts about Employee Onboarding, employees who participate in a structured onboarding program are 69% more likely to stay with an organization for 3 years and more.
It also mentioned that onboarding programs can increase retention by 25% and improve employee performance by 11%.

onboarding_process.title: Onboarding Process
onboarding_process.note: This onboarding process is intended for office-based (production and non-production) employees only and not applicable to production workers. A separate orientation program is applicable to and facilitated for the production workers.

leader_key_responsibilities.title: Key Responsibilities
leader_key_responsibilities.description: As the hiring leader, you have the most influence in making the onboarding process a successful one. You serve as the link that integrates the new employee into the organization. You should be aware that a well-structured onboarding program not only increases employee retention, but also plays a vital role in building positive organizational culture. By making a proper and positive impression, employees will more likely stay and be a productive member of the organization.

responsibilities.title: Clarify job expectations
details: Discuss and review together the employee's duties and responsibilities and how the role impacts the department's goals and priorities.
Ensure the employee understands how to translate expectations into day-to-day activities.

responsibilities.title: Manage performance and provide support
details: Schedule regular meetings to provide continuous direction and support.
Provide feedback, both positive and constructive, on the employee's performance and determine support and resources needed to bridge any gaps.

responsibilities.title: Ensure regular and ongoing communication
details: Discuss the formal and informal culture, values, and practices of the team and the company.
Discuss your preferred leadership, management, communication, problem-solving and decision-making style.

probationary_period.title: PROBATIONARY PERIOD
probationary_period.description: The first one hundred eighty days of a new employee is considered as the most critical period in his/her employment as it would determine his/her success in the organization in terms of job and culture fit. The probationary period helps employers observe the skills, competence, and performance of new employees and determine if they are able to meet the reasonable standards to become regular or permanent employees.
probationary_period.leader_goal: In order to do this, the leader should develop performance goals and expectations, observe and provide regular feedback, and set aside ample time to discuss and evaluate the employee's performance.

legal_reference.description: Under Article 281 of the Labor Code of the Philippines, the maximum length of probationary employment shall be 180 days, and is counted from the date an employee started working, unless it is covered by an apprenticeship agreement stipulating a longer period. The services of an employee who has been engaged on a probationary basis may be terminated for a just cause or when he fails to qualify as a regular employee in accordance with reasonable standards made known by the employer to the employee at the time of his engagement.

third_month.title: On the 3rd Month
third_month.action: It is recommended that you conduct a mid-point performance evaluation to determine whether the new employee is meeting performance standards. It does not have to be through a formal performance evaluation, but you should have some form of documentation.
third_month.purpose: Conducting a mid-point performance review allows the new employee the opportunity to make changes and improvements in his/her performance in the succeeding months before the 5th month performance evaluation.

fourth_month.title: On the 4th Month
fourth_month.action: Upon receiving the notice from HR-Compensation & Benefits on the regularization period of the new employee, you should immediately accomplish the Performance Evaluation Form (PEF). You should be able to submit it on the 5th month with a decision on whether or not to regularize the employee.
fourth_month.note: When the employment is not terminated after the 180-day probationary period, it shall then be considered regular employment.

probationary_period.watch_out: During the probationary period of the new employee, your role is to monitor and review his/her performance based on the goals and expectations that were set and agreed upon since the first day of employment.

department_head_responsibility.description: It is crucial for you to submit the necessary documents and/or inform your HRBP before the 5th month of the probationary period if you are not recommending the employee for regularization since HR needs to provide him/her a 30-day notice prior to the end of his/her contract.

pre_arrival.title: Pre-Arrival
tasks: Check the Onboarding Checklist that will be sent by the Recruitment Team.
Request for computer/laptop setup and account creation (email account, login credentials, access to shared folder, etc.) via CDO IT Freshservice
Ensure workspace is clean with all the necessary equipment and supplies.
Send an announcement via email to concerned parties regarding the new employee. See New Employee Announcement Email template.
Assign an Onboarding Buddy.

Arrange a schedule for the first 1-2 weeks to discuss all necessary information that will help facilitate a smooth onboarding. Prepare information and documents, i.e. job description, organizational charts, strategic plans and priorities, programs, and specific policies and procedures, pertaining to the employee's role and the department/section's functions.
Arrange a welcome lunch on the new employee's first day. (optional)
Ensure that the employee attends the onsite EGCOP class or takes the EGCOP via CDO LIVE.

first_week.title: First Week (1-2 Weeks)
tasks: Send a welcome email to the new employee on his/her first day.
Introduce the new employee to the team, co-workers, and to his/her onboarding buddy.
Issue laptop/computer and orient in the use of computer sign-in/log-in credentials, access to shared drives, and other portals.
Ensure that the employee was provided a copy of the onboarding manual (c/o HRBP).

Conduct a 1-on-1 session with the new employee to discuss his/her duties and responsibilities, the team's organizational structure, plans, priorities, and programs, policies and procedures. It will help if there are available documents that he/she can read and review.

Discuss your leadership/management style, expectations, and ways of working. Discuss communication channels that the team uses, i.e. Viber, Chat, Messenger. Share unwritten rules, nuances, and traditions.
Discuss timekeeping process and application via ESS portal, i.e. work schedule, PTO, OB, OT.
Discuss company policies and guidelines.
Give an office/plant tour through the assigned onboarding buddy, including location of washrooms, ATM, canteen, chapel, training/meeting/conference rooms, emergency exits, activity center.
Review the functions of other departments where relevant.
Plan and discuss the new employee's first assignment/project so that he/she has early success.
Remind the new employee to answer the Quick Onboarding Survey that can be found in the onboarding manual.
Arrange for regular or weekly meetings with the new employee to review and support their integration.

first_3_months.title: First 3 Months
tasks: Schedule regular Kumustahan Sessions with the new employee to touch base, review and clarify performance objectives, expectations, project/assignment updates, and answer any questions.
Provide coaching and continuous feedback. Discuss possible issues and challenges and agree on solution.
Discuss training or workshops that are available and may be beneficial to the employee's development. Review learning and development opportunities.
Remind new employee to answer the 30-60-90 day onboarding survey.
Conduct mid-point performance evaluation.

three_months_up.title: 3 Months Up
tasks: Continue with regular Kumustahan Sessions with the new employee to touch base, review and clarify performance objectives, expectations, project/assignment updates, and answer any questions.
Continue to provide coaching and feedback, including discussion of possible issues and challenges and agree on solution.
Review the onboarding process with the new employee.
Conduct probationary review. Get in touch with HRBP.
Remind new employee to answer the 180-day onboarding survey.
Discuss career development and plans for the future.

onboarding_buddy.title: Assigning an Onboarding Buddy
onboarding_buddy.definition: An Onboarding Buddy is someone who partners with the new employee during the first year of employment and serves as a source of information, advice, guidance, and encouragement in order to steer the new employee in the right direction and helps create and maintain a positive, productive integration.

selection_criteria.title: Criteria for Selecting an Onboarding Buddy:
criteria: Familiar with the organization and the department/section's system and processes
Well-engaged in the organization  appreciates the value of his/her employment with FSI; speaks well of the organization
Familiar with the new employee's role or will be working closely with the new employee
A positive role model; demonstrates high performance
Willing and able to mentor a new hire in order to help him/her easily get integrated in the organization
Has patience and good communication and interpersonal skills

buddy_responsibilities.title: Responsibilities of the Onboarding Buddy:
responsibilities: Be an informal resource on policies, procedures, work rules, norms, traditions, protocols. etc.
Be a tour guide
Guide the new hire in working out some logistics and admin-related concerns especially during the 1st week
Introduce the new employee to others especially with those whom he/she will have constant interaction with

leader_role.title: YOUR ROLE AS A LEADER
responsibilities: Select the best onboarding colleague based on the criteria
Ensure that the new employee has time to be accessible to the new employee
Monitor the onboarding colleague-new employee relationship
Evaluate the program

questions.question: Can the probationary period be extended?
questions.answer: No. Under normal circumstances, the probationary period of an employee should not be extended. The six months probationary period given to the new employee is considered as sufficient time for the employer and the new employee to determine if they have a good fit. However, exceptions may be made in very rare cases or under instances when complete evaluation of the employee's performance will not be possible. For emphasis, the extension must be done in good faith, with justification, and must be agreed upon by both the employer and employee. This should be approved by the Division Head and the HRAD Head.

questions.question: Can a new employee be regularized prior to the regularization period?
questions.answer: No. Early regularization is discouraged unless under extreme circumstances.

questions.question: Is there a salary increase upon regularization?
questions.answer: It is not automatic or guaranteed. However, in rare cases, a minimal adjustment may be recommended by the immediate superior or manager.

questions.question: How do we count the probationary period?
questions.answer: The probationary period begins from the time the employee started working, not on when he/she signed the job offer or the employment contract. The probationary period of 6 months is equal to 180 days.

questions.question: What happens if I was unable to submit the necessary documents past the new employee's probationary period?
questions.answer: The new employee automatically becomes a regular employee regardless of the result of the performance evaluation due to technicality.

Framework.Description: Engage your team members to thrive and contribute their best. Build connection, encourage collaboration, and create a work environment that values open communication, feedback, and recognition. A leader who engages the team ensures that everyone is aligned, motivated, and productive.
Your_Role_as_Leader: Build strong working relationships with your team.
Create opportunities for meaningful dialogue and feedback.
Recognize and celebrate individual and team contributions.
Empower team members by involving them in decision-making.

Engagement_Definition.Description: Employee engagement refers to the emotional commitment that an employee has towards the organization, its goals, and values. It is the level of enthusiasm and connection employees feel toward their work. Engaged employees are motivated to contribute to the organizations success and are more likely to stay within the company for a long time.

Why_Engagement_Matters.Descripttion_1: Employees are more engaged when they feel that their work is positive and fulfilling. They feel proud of, inspired by, and actively involved with their work. They also feel that their employers listen to and care for them.
Engaged_Employees: Show higher productivity and better performance.
Have lower absenteeism and turnover rates.
Why_Engagement_Matters.Descripttion_2: Without employee engagement, there is no team engagement making it difficult to improve business outcomes.
Why_Engagement_Matters.Descripttion_3: Through effective employee engagement initiatives and programs, employees will bring unique benefits to the organization in the form of higher profitability, better customer retention, better talent acquisition and retention, lower employee turnover, and a safer work environment.

Facts: In a 2017 study by Gallup, it was found that only 15 percent of the worlds one billion workers are engaged at work. Thats an alarming statistic. Lower engagement leads to lower productivity and thus, slower economic growth.
Employee engagement leads to +42% in commitment, +38% in employee retention, and +25% in customer focus.

performance_management.title: What is Performance Management?
performance_management.description: A corporate management tool that helps leaders monitor and evaluate employees' work performance.

definition.primary: Performance Management System is the continuous process of improving performance by setting individual and team goals that are aligned to the strategic goals of the organization, planning performance to achieve goals, reviewing and assessing progress, and developing the knowledge, skills, and abilities of people.
definition.secondary: It is an ongoing process of communication between a superior and a subordinate that happens throughout the year. It involves a continuous process of clarifying expectations, setting objectives, identifying goals, providing feedback, and reviewing results/outputs.

leader_responsibilities.introduction: As a leader, your responsibility is to develop a high performance culture at FSI by ensuring the following:

responsibilities.description: Communicate FSI's mission, goals, and values to your team
Clearly define the work standards and expectations with your team and individual members
Conduct regular feedback with your team to keep them informed about their progress towards the achievement of goals
Provide guidance and corrective actions for non-achievement of goals or performance expectations
Communicate and establish a shared belief with regard to the importance of continuously improving performance

key_characteristics: Two-way interaction between superior and subordinate
core_components: Aligning goals to strategic organizational goals

principle.statement: Strong performance management rests on the simple principle that 'what gets measured and tracked gets done'.

overview.description: In an ideal system, a business creates a cascade of metrics and targets, from its top-level strategic objectives down to the daily activities of its frontline employees. Managers continually monitor those metrics and regularly engage with their teams to discuss progress in meeting the targets. Good performance is rewarded; underperformance triggers action to address the problem.

levels.name: Departmental Goals
levels.description: Goals aligned to strategic objectives at department level

levels.name: Individual Goals
levels.description: Goals aligned to departmental goals at individual employee level

stages.name: Planning & Goal Setting
stages.description: Goals are set and individual success metrics defined
stages.timing: Occurs every Q4 in preparation for the succeeding year, with goals finalized by January

stages.name: Monitoring
stages.description: Goals are tracked and feedback is given regularly
stages.timing: Occurs regularly depending on agreed scheduled check-ins (i.e. monthly, quarterly)

stages.name: Evaluating
stages.description: Assess employee's job performance as measured by set expectations

stages.name: Revisiting
stages.description: Goals are reviewed and targets are calibrated

balanced_scorecard.title: The Balanced Scorecard (BSC)
balanced_scorecard.description: The Balanced Scorecard was originally developed by Dr. Robert Kaplan of Harvard University and Dr. David Norton as a framework for measuring organizational performance using a more balanced set of performance measures.

perspectives.question: What are the financial objectives for growth and profitability?

questions: Who are the target customer segments that will generate growth and profit?
What is our value proposition to these target segments?

perspectives.question: What skills should our people excel in, to enable them to perform the key internal processes?
What internal processes should we excel in, to enable us to deliver our value proposition?

framework_structure.balance: Financial and non-financial measures across four perspectives

balanced_scorecard.purpose: Measuring organizational performance using a balanced set of performance measures across four key perspectives

balanced_scorecard_perspectives.title: Balanced Scorecard Perspectives
balanced_scorecard_perspectives.description: The BSC suggests that we examine an organization from four different perspectives to help develop objectives, measures (KPIs), targets, and initiatives relative to those views.

purpose_of_bsc.title: Purpose of the BSC
organizational_uses: Communicate what they are trying to accomplish
Align the day-to-day work that everyone is doing with strategy
Measure and monitor progress towards strategic targets

financial_measures.description: Tell the results of actions already taken

purpose_of_bsc.balance_concept: The balanced scorecard includes financial measures that tell the results of actions already taken. And it complements the financial measures with operational measures on customer satisfaction, internal processes, and the organization's innovation and improvement activitiesoperational measures that are the drivers of future financial performance.

cascading_of_bsc.title: Cascading of BSC
cascading_of_bsc.definition: Cascading a balanced scorecard means to translate the corporate-wide scorecard starting from the top and rolling down into a department, group, and even up to the employee level.
cascading_of_bsc.purpose: Cascading strategy focuses the entire organization on strategy and creating the connection between the work people do and high level desired results. As the management system is cascaded down through the organization, objectives become more operational and tactical, as do the performance measures. Accountability follows the objectives and measures, as ownership is defined at each level. This alignment step is critical to becoming a strategy-focused organization.

steps.name: Division BSC Approved
steps.description: Division-level balanced scorecard is reviewed and approved

steps.name: Agree on LEAD Targets Per KPI
steps.description: Leadership agrees on target metrics for each key performance indicator

steps.name: Assign Responsible Depts/Units
steps.description: Departments and units are assigned ownership of specific KPIs

steps.name: Managers Assign Individual Targets
steps.description: Managers cascade targets down to individual employee level

steps.name: Individual Target Setting Discussion
steps.description: One-on-one discussions between managers and employees to set individual targets

steps.name: Teams Create Performance Dashboards
steps.description: Teams develop dashboards to monitor and track performance

implementation_process.flow: Linear progression from division approval to operational dashboards

key_principles: Translation of corporate strategy to all levels
Alignment of work with strategic objectives

lead_and_lag_measures.title: LEAD and LAG Measures

quote.text: Focusing on the wildly important requires you to go against your basic wiring as a leader to do more, and instead, focus on less so that your team can achieve more.
quote.author: Sean Covey
quote.source: Co-author of The 4 Disciplines of Execution

lead_measures.title: LEAD
lead_measures.definition: An indicator of performance that might predict future success.
characteristics: Are predictive measurement
Give early indications of performance
Keep you on track as they show the progress you're making toward your goal
Are controllable
Can influence change
lead_measures.description: Lead measures track the critical activities that drive or lead to the lag measure. They are in-process measures. They are things like new market development, number of sales calls made, calories consumed per day, and safety training.

monitoring.recommendation: Consider putting them in a dashboard so you can track them in real time on a daily or weekly basis.

lag_measures.title: LAG
lag_measures.definition: An indicator of past performance that measures how an individual or a team performed.
characteristics: Are output/after-the-event measurement
Take a long time to impact or measure
Most accurately measure the actual business impact you're trying to achieve
Are unpredictable and uncontrollable
Only records what has happened
lag_measures.examples: Lags are things like revenue, profit, quality, accident rate, and customer satisfaction. They are called lags because by the time you see them, the performance that drove them has already passed.
lag_measures.limitation: You can do nothing to fix them.

monitoring.frequency: Take a long time to change so there's no need to track them on a daily or weekly basis
monitoring.recommendation: They can be checked less frequently, monthly or quarterly, depending on the metric.

actionability.lead: Can be acted upon to influence outcomes
actionability.lag: Cannot be changed after the fact

lead_and_lag_measures.relationship: Lead measures drive lag measures. Focus on lead measures to influence lag measure outcomes.

lead_and_lag_measures_examples.title: Strategic Objectives with Lead and Lag Measures

context.recommendation: It has been customary for businesses to just use lagging indicators to measure success. However, since it takes a long time to see results and it prohibits teams to make the necessary ongoing adjustments, it has been recommended to use a combination of lead and lag measures.
context.benefit: Using lead and lag indicators result in enhanced business performance overall. Inasmuch as a Balanced Scorecard requires a 'balance' of measures across organizational disciplines, so a 'balance' of lead and lag indicators are required to ensure the right activities are in place to guarantee the right outcomes.

perspectives.description: Usually this section concerns itself with key financial data such as revenue, cost of sale, gross margin, expenses and net profit, however it can also include financial initiatives such as risk assessments and cost-benefit analysis.

objectives.lead_measure: Add three more products to the portfolio this year

perspectives.description: The company seen from the customer's viewpoint. Unsatisfied customers will look for other suppliers to meet their needs. Customer satisfaction is in itself a lead indicator that can predict potential future loss.
The ability to determine how well the business is running and whether or not the products and/or services meet the needs of its customers and are aligned to the companies objectives.

The main resource in most companies today is its people, it is essential, especially in a climate where technology is changing rapidly, that they grow and learn continuously. Focus has to be on where best to spend ever decreasing budgets.

key_insights.balance_required: A 'balance' of lead and lag indicators are required to ensure the right activities are in place to guarantee the right outcomes
key_insights.business_impact: Using lead and lag indicators result in enhanced business performance overall
key_insights.measurement_approach: Combination of lead and lag measures recommended over just lagging indicators alone

phase_1.name: Performance Planning
phase_1.description: Performance Management begins with a planning session wherein goals, Key Result Areas (KRA), Key Performance Indicators (KPI), targets, and work standards are established and mutually agreed upon by the immediate superior and the subordinate.
purpose_of_written_performance_expectati: Serves as an objective and tangible basis in discussing performance
Allows the employee to distinguish between acceptable and unacceptable results or work output
Increases job satisfaction since employees are aware when tasks performed or results meet expectations
Informs new employees of your expectations about job performance
Encourages an open, collaborative, and trusting relationship with employees

measurement.results: Often measured based on the established standards and objectives
measurement.actions_and_behaviors: Can be measured through performance dimensions

performance_expectations.requirements: It is important that the performance expectations are written, verifiable, and mutually understood by both the immediate superior and the employee.

kra.title: Key Result Areas (KRAs)
kra.definition: KRAs refer to the general areas of outcomes or outputs for which a role, or a combination of roles, is responsible. These are the main goals which are critical for an organization or employee to achieve to be successful. KRAs will differ significantly depending on the role of an employee or the specific goals of a department or an organization.
guiding_questions: What does success look like for the employee/department/organization?
What is the relatively small portion of your work that brings the most value to your organization?
kra.focus_areas: The KRA for an organization should focus on the vital areas that fit best with an organization's strategic goals and most directly drive its success.
leader_questions_for_development: What is the purpose of every position that reports to you?
Why is each staff member employed by your organization?
For each employee, create a list of vital tasks they've been hired to do.
Arrange the tasks based on their importance to your organization.

key_elements_for_individual_kra.name: Begin with a conversation
key_elements_for_individual_kra.description: It is crucial for an immediate superior to meet and discuss with the employee in preparing and writing the KRA for the position. This is an opportunity for both parties to consider and agree on the appropriate goals that will be measured for the position.

key_elements_for_individual_kra.name: Broadly define the job profile
key_elements_for_individual_kra.description: KRAs should be able to give a general description of the job and clarity on the role and mission of the employee within the organization.

key_elements_for_individual_kra.name: Create SMART KRAs
key_elements_for_individual_kra.description: KRAs should be Specific, Measurable, Attainable, Relevant, and Time-bound.

key_elements_for_individual_kra.name: Set a limited and realistic number
key_elements_for_individual_kra.description: KRAs refer to the most important objectives and should, therefore, be limited to the critical few. A typical area targets three to five KRAs. This helps determine the most valuable indicators, makes tracking easier, and aids in allocating resources to that which will reap the greatest value.

key_elements_for_individual_kra.name: Put it in writing
key_elements_for_individual_kra.description: KRAs must be written, reviewed, agreed upon, and signed by all parties involved.

kpi.title: Key Performance Indicators (KPIs)
kpi.definition: KPIs refer to any metric/criteria that measures or evaluates the performance in the Key Result Areas (KRAs), which linked back to the achievement of the department/organization objectives, and the achievement of the organization's goals. KPIs can involve sales figures, product performance, return on investments, savings, and a wide range of other areas that are quantifiable or have observable indicators.
guiding_questions: How will the KRA be measured?
How will I assess our progress towards the achievement of our goals?

expression_types.description: The amount of time needed to complete a certain task or activity; answers the questions: by when, how soon, or within what period
Specifies how much work must be completed within a certain period of time
Describes how well the work must be accomplished; specifies accuracy, precision, appearance, or effectiveness
Used when performance can be reviewed in terms of utilization of resources: money saved, waste reduced, income generated

examples.kpi: % growth of follower base converted to sales
# of issues resolved within a set timeline

examples.target: Reduce downtime incidents in production to 0

kpi.note: KPIs must be submitted to the HRBP for proper documentation.

values_and_behaviors.title: Values: Defining Actions and Behaviors
values_and_behaviors.section: II. Values: Defining Actions and Behaviors
values_and_behaviors.rationale: Performance expectations cannot be satisfied solely by results. It is important to consider other aspects of performance that will lead to the achievement of established objectives and standards, such as actions and behaviors. Understanding how employees act and behave in order to perform their job is also important to success as the end results.
values_and_behaviors.principle: It is believed that the manner by which employees conduct themselves in carrying out their work will largely impact the outcome or the results that will be produced. It is therefore vital that leaders also focus on and assess the way people go about their work.
values_and_behaviors.leader_responsibility: As a leader, you should be able to identify and quantify aspects of performance to make them specific, observable, job-related, and behavioral. You start by defining the job and stating the range of behaviors the employees must exhibit to successfully perform the job based on expectations and standards.

dimensions.definition: These behaviors may be grouped into broad categories called dimensions, which answer the question: 'How does an employee act and/or behave when s/he does the job well?'

cdo_implementation.measurement_approach: At CDO, this dimension is being measured using the company's core values with behavioral descriptions indicated per job level.

characteristics: Specific
Observable
Job-related
Behavioral

engage_phase.documentation_requirement: KPIs must be submitted to the HRBP for proper documentation

phase_2.name: Performance Monitoring
phase_2.description: Once the Key Result Areas, Key Performance Indicators, and targets have been established, your role as a leader is to observe the employee's performance and check-in with them regularly by providing feedback.
leader_responsibilities: Monitor the progress of the activities that have been identified in relation to the accomplishment of the department or individual goals
Recognize and reinforce strong performance by the employees and the team
Identify and encourage improvement areas where necessary

periodic_feedback_sessions.purpose: You may conduct periodic feedback sessions to discuss actual performance, particularly problems and difficulties encountered and agreed resolution to said problems.
periodic_feedback_sessions.importance: This is critical for employees on probation as this will be the major deciding factor for his/her regularization.
periodic_feedback_sessions.process: You can show and discuss the employee's rating based on actual accomplishments as well as significant observations during the covered evaluation period. The employee will also be given the opportunity to respond and propose a plan of action particularly on areas of performance that need improvement.

dashboard.title: Example of a Dashboard
dashboard.description: In order to monitor performance, you may create a dashboard that the team can use as reference in checking and assessing the progress of your KRA/KPI. This can be reviewed monthly or weekly.

examples.target: From average of 20 to 40 per month
From average of 20 to 5 per month

examples.kpi: # of issues resolved within set timeline

target: From average of 5 to 1 per month

phase_3.name: Performance Review/Evaluation
phase_3.description: Review provides an opportunity for the leader to communicate with the employee with regard to past performance, evaluate the employee's job satisfaction, and make plans for the employee's future performance.
phase_3.definition: Performance review is the process of measuring an employee's performance in the current position based on the agreed standards and expectations. This is also known as appraisal, evaluation, or assessment.
phase_3.summary: The performance evaluation summarizes the employee's contribution over the entire review period. Depending on the organization's policy, an employee can be formally assessed once or twice a year. However, it is suggested that employees receive some form of evaluation or assessment on a more frequent basis or as often as necessary.
benefits: Lift employee morale through appreciation of contributions

frequency.title: Frequency

categories.description: Each probationary employee shall be formally evaluated on the fourth month of the probation period in order to serve as basis for personnel action (either for regularization or termination of contract).
All regular employees are to be evaluated fully annually. This is being held every January covering the months of January to December of the previous year.

occasions: When an employee is being considered for promotion
When a contractual or project-based employee is being considered for a regular or permanent position
When an employee is undergoing a Performance Improvement Plan (PIP)

leader_role: Accomplish the Performance Evaluation Form (PEF) of each of the employee reporting under you and submit it on a timely manner, based on the submission guidelines released by HRAD through the HR Business Partners
Ensure that the discussion with each employee takes place

components_of_rating.title: Components of Rating

kpi.description: The KPI rating is derived from actual accomplishments/outputs versus set targets as agreed by both the immediate superior and the employee during the performance planning phase.

cdo_values.description: The employee is also evaluated based on certain dimensions and indicators in relation to the Company's core values, each has a corresponding qualitative description. The employee will be rated according to the degree by which said attributes are being exhibited. Specific critical incidents should be cited. It is recommended that the superior maintains a record of work-related behavior, whether positive or negative, demonstrated by the employee.

components_of_rating.note: As an internal process, you may encourage your staff to do a self-assessment first during the performance review period. This will allow them to become more aware of their own strengths and areas for improvement. Thus, enabling them to participate more constructively when you meet for the performance discussion.
